paper.title: Creating large, high-quality geospatial datasets from historical maps using novice volunteers

claims.claim_text: Unlocking data from historical maps for landscape analysis is costly
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlocking data from historical maps for landscape analysis is costly.

claims.claim_text: Automatic extraction using Machine Learning requires extensive preparation and expertise
claims.verbatim_quote: Automatic extraction using Machine Learning (ML) requires extensive preparation and expertise.

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing scales better than direct digitisation by experts but requires an appropriate platform and technical skills to adapt it
claims.verbatim_quote: Crowdsourcing scales better than direct digitisation by experts, but requires an appropriate platform and the technical skills to adapt it.

claims.claim_text: Existing research provides little guidance as to when investments in digitisation approaches become worthwhile
claims.verbatim_quote: Existing research provides little guidance as to when investments in these approaches become worthwhile.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps.

claims.claim_text: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers)
claims.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers)

claims.claim_text: The digitisation had an error rate under 6%
claims.verbatim_quote: with an error rate under 6%

claims.claim_text: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing
claims.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features
claims.verbatim_quote: A conservative estimate based on our work suggests our crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features

claims.claim_text: The approach may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records
claims.verbatim_quote: but may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records

claims.claim_text: Systems designed for field data collection running on mobile devices can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers
claims.verbatim_quote: it indicates that systems designed for field data collection, running on mobile devices, can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers.

claims.claim_text: The value of this approach lies in the unanticipated success of a minimally resourced digitisation effort
claims.verbatim_quote: The value of this approach lies in the unanticipated success of a minimally resourced digitisation effort

claims.claim_text: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, the approach required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset
claims.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

claims.claim_text: The approach complements Machine Learning and other automated approaches in that it requires less technical expertise, time, and resourcing to undertake
claims.verbatim_quote: It complements Machine Learning (ML) and other automated approaches in that it requires less technical expertise, time, and resourcing to undertake.

claims.claim_text: The approach is suitable for projects working with small to mid-sized data sources (100s–10,000s of features) that do not warrant the investment needed for successful ML-based data extraction
claims.verbatim_quote: Such an approach is suitable for projects working with small to mid-sized data sources (100s–10,000s of features) that do not warrant the investment needed for successful ML-based data extraction

claims.claim_text: TRAP has explored long-term cultural development in its environmental context since 2008
claims.verbatim_quote: It has explored long-term cultural development in its environmental context since 2008

claims.claim_text: Between 2008 and 2016, TRAP catalogued some 773 mounds in the Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in the Yambol region using pedestrian surface survey supported by manual digitisation of satellite imagery and maps
claims.verbatim_quote: Between 2008 and 2016, TRAP catalogued some 773 mounds in the Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in the Yambol region using pedestrian surface survey supported by manual digitisation of satellite imagery and maps.

claims.claim_text: During 2017 and 2018, TRAP digitised mounds from over 20,000 sq km of Soviet military 1:50,000 topographic maps covering southeast Bulgaria
claims.verbatim_quote: (3) digitising mounds from over 20,000 sq km of Soviet military 1:50,000 topographic maps covering southeast Bulgaria

claims.claim_text: An estimated 50,000 burial mounds were built in Bulgarian lands from the Early Bronze Age through the Middle Ages
claims.verbatim_quote: An estimated 50,000 burial mounds were built in Bulgarian lands from the Early Bronze Age through the Middle Ages

claims.claim_text: Burial mounds range in size from 10 to 50 m in diameter and 0.5–20 m in height
claims.verbatim_quote: range in size from 10 to 50 m in diameter and 0.5–20 m in height

claims.claim_text: Burial mounds are at risk of looting
claims.verbatim_quote: Because they may contain intrinsically valuable grave goods, mounds are at risk of looting

claims.claim_text: Some mounds are destroyed in the course of development, sometimes preceded by rescue excavations
claims.verbatim_quote: Others are destroyed in the course of development, sometimes preceded by rescue excavations

claims.claim_text: Some mounds are degraded by agricultural activities, particularly as pasturelands are repurposed to arable farming
claims.verbatim_quote: Still others are degraded by agricultural activities, particularly as pasturelands are repurposed to arable farming

claims.claim_text: Historical maps help heritage specialists analyse change over time in order to monitor and mitigate various impacts
claims.verbatim_quote: Historical maps help heritage specialists analyse change over time in order to monitor and mitigate the impact of urban development, climate change, biodiversity loss, erosion, agricultural extensification, and other kinds of land use and environmental changes

claims.claim_text: The value of historical maps has been underexploited due to the entailed process of manual digitisation needed to transform analogue information into machine-readable data
claims.verbatim_quote: The value of such maps has, however, been underexploited due to the entailed process of manual digitisation needed to transform their analogue information into machine-readable data.

claims.claim_text: Manually drawing and annotating shapes in historical maps using a desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills
claims.verbatim_quote: Manually drawing and annotating shapes in historical maps using a desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills

claims.claim_text: The principal limitations of manual desktop GIS digitisation are difficulty of scaling the effort, particularly restricted time and availability of expert users
claims.verbatim_quote: Its principal limitations are difficulty of scaling the effort, particularly restricted time and availability of expert users to either undertake digitisation themselves, or to train and support novices to the extent required for efficient and accurate work

claims.claim_text: ML has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: ML has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation

claims.claim_text: ML requires specific programming expertise and familiarity with the capabilities and limitations of ML
claims.verbatim_quote: but it requires specific programming expertise, and familiarity with the capabilities and limitations of ML

claims.claim_text: Naive use of ML is likely to produce biased or otherwise unreliable results
claims.verbatim_quote: Naive use of ML is likely to produce biased or otherwise unreliable results

claims.claim_text: Training an ML algorithm requires manual creation and preparation of training data and manual quality assurance
claims.verbatim_quote: Training an algorithm, moreover, requires manual creation and preparation of training data and manual quality assurance

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing has only rarely been used to extract the location of archaeological features from symbols on historical maps
claims.verbatim_quote: but crowdsourcing has only rarely been used to extract the location of archaeological features from symbols on historical maps

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing offers advantages compared to alternative approaches under many, if not most, map digitisation scenarios
claims.verbatim_quote: This paper argues that crowdsourcing offers advantages compared to alternative approaches under many, if not most, map digitisation scenarios.

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing requires more upfront investment in system setup than using available GIS specialists or training volunteers using desktop GIS, but it scales better
claims.verbatim_quote: Crowdsourcing requires more upfront investment in system setup than using available GIS specialists or training and supervising volunteers using desktop GIS, but it scales better in the face of likely constraints related to expert staffing and volunteer attrition.

claims.claim_text: Compared to ML, crowdsourcing requires less specialised and hard-to-come-by expertise, requires less time for initial setup, and produces high-quality datasets with more predictable errors
claims.verbatim_quote: Compared to ML, it requires less specialised and hard-to-come-by expertise, requires less time for initial setup, and produces high-quality datasets with more predictable errors.

claims.claim_text: The expertise necessary to use a GIS has hindered collaboration between specialists and the broader community in the past
claims.verbatim_quote: The expertise necessary to use a GIS has hindered collaboration between specialists and the broader community in the past

claims.claim_text: Producing and manipulating geospatial data challenges novice users more than other data tasks
claims.verbatim_quote: Producing and manipulating geospatial data, even if it is limited to 'simple' activities like symbol digitisation, challenges novice users more than other data tasks.

claims.claim_text: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software
claims.verbatim_quote: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software

claims.claim_text: Mobile applications may be particularly suited to the production of Volunteered Geographic Information
claims.verbatim_quote: Mobile applications may be particularly suited to the production of Volunteered Geographic Information (VGI).

claims.claim_text: Zooniverse observes that mobile-enabled projects receive more classifications than others
claims.verbatim_quote: Zooniverse, a popular platform for large-scale volunteer research participation, observes that 'mobile-enabled projects receive more classifications' than others

claims.claim_text: TRAP staff created a simplified and streamlined data capture system built using the FAIMS Mobile platform for the 2017–2018 field seasons
claims.verbatim_quote: For the 2017–2018 field seasons, TRAP staff created a simplified and streamlined data capture system built using the FAIMS Mobile platform.

claims.claim_text: This system allowed any number of participants to digitise map features using mobile devices, regardless of network connectivity
claims.verbatim_quote: This system allowed any number of participants to digitise map features using mobile devices, regardless of network connectivity, and consolidated the resulting data when a network became available.

claims.claim_text: The goal was to extract archaeological features from 1:50,000 scale Soviet military topographic maps dating to the 1980s
claims.verbatim_quote: The goal of the work was to extract archaeological features from 1:50,000 scale Soviet military topographic maps dating to the 1980s.

claims.claim_text: Mound symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400
claims.verbatim_quote: Such symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400.

claims.claim_text: The students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities with most having no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods
claims.verbatim_quote: Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities. Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods

claims.claim_text: In 2010, project staff worked with student volunteers to digitise map features using ArcGIS but found that novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging
claims.verbatim_quote: In 2010, project staff worked with student volunteers to digitise map features using ArcGIS. Our experience was much like that of other projects: novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging

claims.claim_text: Volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered the 2010 desktop GIS approach unsuccessful
claims.verbatim_quote: In the end, volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered this approach unsuccessful.

claims.claim_text: The approach stripped GIS functionality to its essentials, focusing on three tasks: layer selection, shape digitisation, and annotation
claims.verbatim_quote: As such, it stripped GIS functionality to its essentials, focusing on three tasks: layer selection, shape digitisation, and annotation, with validation and automation to improve data quality.

claims.claim_text: A simple and intuitive UI allowed students to begin digitising after only minutes of training
claims.verbatim_quote: while a simple and intuitive UI allowed students to begin digitising after only minutes of training

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is a server-client platform that generates customised Android applications for data collection during offline field research
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is a server-client platform that generates customised Android applications for data collection during offline field research.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile had previously been used with some success for a student-led ceramics recording project
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile had previously been used with some success for a student-led ceramics recording project

claims.claim_text: The decision to use mobile software was based on FAIMS Mobile working offline
claims.verbatim_quote: The decision to use mobile software, and FAIMS Mobile in particular, was based on several factors. First, FAIMS Mobile worked offline.

claims.claim_text: Student volunteers are accustomed to, and even prefer, slippy-map, touch-screen interfaces on mobile devices over the point-and-click, desktop UI idiom
claims.verbatim_quote: Fifth, student volunteers are accustomed to, and even prefer, 'slippy-map', touch-screen interfaces on mobile devices over the point-and-click, desktop UI idiom.

claims.claim_text: No existing system met the requirements off-the-shelf without significant customisation
claims.verbatim_quote: No existing system met these requirements 'off-the-shelf', without significant customisation

claims.claim_text: ESRI ArcGIS Collector and Survey123 had disadvantages including the need to divide map-centric and form-centric recording between two applications
claims.verbatim_quote: The primary alternatives assessed, ESRI ArcGIS Collector (now succeeded by Field Maps) and Survey123, had a number of disadvantages, particularly the need to divide map-centric and form-centric recording between the two applications and reconcile the data later

claims.claim_text: The stages of FAIMS Mobile implementation included seven distinct steps from data modeling to accuracy checking
claims.verbatim_quote: The stages of FAIMS Mobile implementation (Fig. 3) included: (1) project staff modelled the data and workflow to ensure that the final dataset met research needs, (2) a junior software developer worked with project staff to customise the system, (3) project staff defined a spatial reference system (SRS) and imported preprocessed historical maps, (4) volunteers drew a shape (usually a point) wherever they saw a target symbol and (5) volunteers transcribed attributes from the map, (6) project staff exported data using the FAIMS Mobile server, (7) project staff undertook a targeted accuracy-checking exercise.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile automated numerous tasks including applying spatial reference system, rendering maps, enforcing shape topology, and recording metadata
claims.verbatim_quote: To support this workflow and make work easier for both project staff and participants, FAIMS Mobile automated a number of tasks and provided necessary capabilities. It applied the spatial reference system, rendered maps in the workspace, provided layer management (including a data entry layer), enforced shape topology, displayed pre-defined controlled vocabularies for attribute terms, recorded creation time and author for each record, maintained a history of all changes to data, applied validation to ensure record completeness, merged data from multiple devices, and exported data in common formats.

claims.claim_text: Volunteers were insulated from the friction of setup, layer management, data aggregation, export, and backup
claims.verbatim_quote: Since project staff set up the infrastructure and pre-processed and loaded the required maps, volunteers were insulated from the friction of setup, layer management, data aggregation, export, and backup.

claims.claim_text: Exported data was consistent and complete, ready for analysis with minimal cleaning
claims.verbatim_quote: Exported data was consistent and complete, ready for analysis with minimal cleaning.

claims.claim_text: The data adhered to key elements of the FAIR data principles, especially the production of rich and plural metadata at the time of data creation
claims.verbatim_quote: This data adhered to key elements of the FAIR data principles, especially the production of 'rich' and 'plural' metadata at the time of data creation (principles F2, R1.1–1.3; GO-FAIR, 2017).

claims.claim_text: To measure inputs, project staff collated the amount of time spent by various participants including programmers, volunteers, and staff
claims.verbatim_quote: To measure inputs, we collated the amount of time spent by various participants in the process, including the student programmer who instantiated the customisation, the student volunteers who undertook the digitisation, and project staff who configured the system, supported volunteers, exported data, and checked for errors.

claims.claim_text: For the first season of use (2017), creating the Map Digitisation customisation required 35 h from an undergraduate student programmer plus 4 h from staff
claims.verbatim_quote: For the first season of use (2017), creating the Map Digitisation customisation of FAIMS Mobile required 35 h from an undergraduate student programmer plus 4 h from staff

claims.claim_text: Setup of the server and configuration of client devices in the field required 3 h from staff
claims.verbatim_quote: Setup of the server and configuration of the client devices in the field required 3 h from staff.

claims.claim_text: Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h
claims.verbatim_quote: Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h.

claims.claim_text: Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire 2017 season
claims.verbatim_quote: Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.

claims.claim_text: For the second season, adding additional validation took 1 h of development from the programmer
claims.verbatim_quote: For the second season, adding additional validation to ensure population of latitude and longitude from GPS (see 'Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records' below) took 1 h of development from the programmer.

claims.claim_text: Across both seasons, customisation, setup, and supervision took about 51 h, including 36 h from the programmer and 15 from project staff
claims.verbatim_quote: Across both seasons, customisation, setup, and supervision took about 51 h, including 36 h from the programmer and 15 from project staff.

claims.claim_text: Re-examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, re-examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.

claims.claim_text: In 2017, the system was used for 125.8 person-hours concentrated across five rainy days, during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps
claims.verbatim_quote: In 2017, it was used for a total of 125.8 person-hours concentrated across five rainy days, during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km).

claims.claim_text: The average time to record a point feature in 2017 was 54 s
claims.verbatim_quote: The average time to record a point feature was 54 s, based on start and end times of feature creation as recorded by the devices

claims.claim_text: In 2018, the system was used for 63.6 person-hours, with 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps, an average rate of one record every 92 s
claims.verbatim_quote: In 2018, use was more sporadic; participants who stayed at the base for any reason sometimes undertook digitisation. The system was used for 63.6 person-hours, with 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km), an average rate of one record every 92 s.

claims.claim_text: In total, 10,827 point features were recorded in 189.4 student-hours (63 s per record)
claims.verbatim_quote: In total, 10,827 point features, mostly burial and settlement mounds, were recorded in 189.4 student-hours (63 s per record).

claims.claim_text: The concentrated digitisation in 2017 was more productive than the intermittent work of 2018
claims.verbatim_quote: The concentrated digitisation in 2017 was more productive than the intermittent work of 2018

claims.claim_text: The 2010 digitisation effort using ArcGIS produced a dataset of 915 features and required about 5–7 h of staff training, support, and error-checking over a three-week period
claims.verbatim_quote: Although we did not maintain detailed volunteer time-on-task records, we know this effort produced a dataset of 915 features and required about 5–7 h of staff training, support, and error-checking over a three-week period (based on our field journals).

claims.claim_text: One persistent student accounted for almost all the digitised features in the 2010 effort; without his perseverance, the digitisation effort would have failed entirely
claims.verbatim_quote: Indeed, one persistent student accounted for almost all the digitised features; without his perseverance, the digitisation effort would have failed entirely.

claims.claim_text: The customised mobile application met fundamental usability requirements due to careful design and implementation of Google's Material Design guidelines
claims.verbatim_quote: By contrast, our customised application met fundamental usability requirements (e.g., Nielsen, 2012), both due to careful design of the customisation itself, and the underlying platform's implementation of Google's Material Design guidelines.

claims.claim_text: Automated extraction of coordinates from GPS into fields took three to 5 s with an empty database but took as long as 30 s once a device exceeded about 2,500 records
claims.verbatim_quote: In use, automated extraction of coordinates from GPS into the Latitude/Longitude and Northing/Easting fields, which took three to 5 s with an empty database, took as long as 30 s once a device exceeded about 2,500 records.

claims.claim_text: The best digitisers could be both fast and accurate, while the poorest digitisers were often neither fast nor accurate
claims.verbatim_quote: The best digitisers, furthermore, could be both fast and accurate, while the poorest digitisers were often neither fast nor accurate

claims.claim_text: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records), including 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions
claims.verbatim_quote: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records), including 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions.

claims.claim_text: Most omissions occurred in 2017 when 192 records (2.3%) had empty latitude and longitude fields and 17 (0.2%) were missing specification of the map symbol
claims.verbatim_quote: Most occurred in 2017 when 192 records (2.3%) had empty latitude and longitude fields and 17 (0.2%) were missing specification of the map symbol.

claims.claim_text: In 2018, after validation was added, there were only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%)
claims.verbatim_quote: Before the 2018 season, we added validation addressing this problem, resulting in only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%).

claims.claim_text: Overall accuracy was high, over 94% for processed maps
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlike some volunteer digitisation projects, overall accuracy was high, over 94% for processed maps.

claims.claim_text: A review by project staff of four randomly selected maps found 49 errors from a true count of 834 features, a 5.87% error rate
claims.verbatim_quote: Second, a review by project staff of four randomly selected maps (7% of the total) found 49 errors from a true count of 834 features, a 5.87% error rate

claims.claim_text: Forty-two of the errors were false negatives (symbols missed by students)
claims.verbatim_quote: Forty-two of these errors were false negatives (symbols missed by students).

claims.claim_text: Students made only one classification error and no outright false positives
claims.verbatim_quote: Students made only one classification error (a similar symbol mistaken for a benchmark), and no outright false positives.

claims.claim_text: Students' individual error rates ranged from 1.3% to 10.6%
claims.verbatim_quote: Students' individual error rates ranged from 1.3% to 10.6%.

claims.claim_text: The two fastest digitisers (Students A and B; 44 and 45 s per feature respectively) also had the lowest error rates (1.3 and 2.9%)
claims.verbatim_quote: Note that the two fastest digitisers (Students A and B; 44 and 45 s per feature respectively) also had the lowest error rates (1.3 and 2.9%)

claims.claim_text: The two slowest digitisers (Students C and D; 61 and 73 s) had the highest error rates (10.6 and 7.4%)
claims.verbatim_quote: while the two slowest (Students C and D; 61 and 73 s) had the highest error rates (10.6 and 7.4%)

claims.claim_text: 35 of the 49 false negatives were the result of Student C failing to digitise three contiguous sections of an assigned map
claims.verbatim_quote: Moreover, 35 of the 49 false negatives were the result of Student C failing to digitise three contiguous sections of an assigned map.

claims.claim_text: Excluding Student C would have cut the cumulative error rate in half to 2.8%
claims.verbatim_quote: These mistakes made his error rate of 10.6% an outlier; excluding Student C would have cut the cumulative error rate in half to 2.8%.

claims.claim_text: The pattern of errors made them relatively easy to identify and correct
claims.verbatim_quote: Moreover, the pattern of errors - mostly false negatives and double-marked features, mostly from contiguous map sections - made them relatively easy to identify and correct.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourced digitisation effort involving novice volunteers using an adapted mobile application proved unexpectedly successful
claims.verbatim_quote: Our crowdsourced digitisation effort involving novice volunteers using an adapted mobile application proved unexpectedly successful.

claims.claim_text: The digitisation approach was done under field conditions, with inexpensive equipment and limited internet connectivity, yet produced a large (>10,000 features), high-quality (<6% error rate) dataset
claims.verbatim_quote: Our approach was done under field conditions, with inexpensive equipment and limited internet connectivity, yet produced a large (>10,000 features), high-quality (<6% error rate) dataset

claims.claim_text: After brief workspace setup, project staff with desktop GIS experience could digitise at a sustained rate of 60–75 features per staff-hour
claims.verbatim_quote: After brief workspace setup, project staff with desktop GIS experience could digitise at a sustained rate of 60–75 features per staff-hour.

claims.claim_text: At the staff digitisation rate, the 57 h of staff time devoted to setup, support, and quality assurance for the crowdsourcing system could have resulted in some 3,420–4,275 staff-digitised features
claims.verbatim_quote: At this rate, the 57 h of staff time devoted to set-up, support, and quality assurance for our crowdsourcing system could have resulted in some 3,420–4,275 staff-digitised features

claims.claim_text: Based on 2010 digitisation rate, 57 staff hours supervising volunteers with desktop GIS might have produced 7,410–10,260 features
claims.verbatim_quote: Had specialist project staff instead trained and supervised volunteers to use desktop GIS for digitisation, based on our 2010 digitisation rate of 130–180 features per staff-hour, 57 h might have produced 7,410–10,260 features.

claims.claim_text: The 57 h of staff time required for the crowdsourcing approach produced 10,827 features, or about 190 features per staff-hour
claims.verbatim_quote: By comparison, the 57 h of staff time required for our digitisation approach using a customisation of FAIMS Mobile produced 10,827 features, or about 190 features per staff-hour.

claims.claim_text: Only 21 of the 57 h needed to support the system came from project staff, while the other 36 h were completed by a student programmer for a modest cost (ca. AUD $2,000)
claims.verbatim_quote: First, customisation of systems like FAIMS Mobile can be outsourced more easily than other project activities. Only 21 of the 57 h needed to support the system came from project staff, while the other 36 h were completed by a student programmer for a modest cost (ca. AUD $2,000).

claims.claim_text: Those 21 internal staff hours represent a digitisation rate of over 500 features per staff-hour
claims.verbatim_quote: Those 21 internal staff hours represent a digitisation rate of over 500 features per staff-hour.

claims.claim_text: In-field support for volunteers was only 7 h, representing about 1,550 features per in-field staff-hour
claims.verbatim_quote: Across two seasons, in-field support for volunteers was only 7 h, representing about 1,550 features per in-field staff-hour.

claims.claim_text: The marginal cost for each additional feature digitised is low, translating to 4.3 s of staff support per additional feature
claims.verbatim_quote: Third, the marginal cost for each additional feature digitised is low. This figure includes in-field support and quality assurance (13 h), and translates to 4.3 s of staff support per additional feature.

claims.claim_text: Adding more volunteers does not increase setup time at all
claims.verbatim_quote: Adding more volunteers does not increase setup time at all.

claims.claim_text: Preparing and distributing additional maps took only 6 min per map (6 h for 58 maps)
claims.verbatim_quote: Preparing and distributing additional maps took only 6 min per map (6 h for 58 maps).

claims.claim_text: Adding another field season only costs one additional hour of setup time
claims.verbatim_quote: Even adding another field season only costs one additional hour of setup time (based on our 2018 redeployment).

claims.claim_text: The Urban Occupations Project reported 1,250 h of manual digitisation to create training data plus seven days testing and fine tuning an ML model
claims.verbatim_quote: This project reported 1,250 h of manual digitisation to create enough training data to classify roads visible in historical maps of the Ottoman Empire. Using this input, and after additional preprocessing and filtering, an ML expert spent seven days testing and fine tuning the model.

claims.claim_text: The ML approach appears to have required a minimum of about 1,300 h of preparation time alone
claims.verbatim_quote: This example, which appears to have required a minimum of about 1,300 h of preparation time alone

claims.claim_text: At the crowdsourcing rate of 44.9 features/person-hour, the 1,300 h needed for ML would yield about 58,400 records
claims.verbatim_quote: We spent 44 staff hours customising and deploying a streamlined geospatial system in FAIMS Mobile, 184 participant-hours digitising features, seven staff-hours directly supporting that digitisation, and six staff hours checking for errors. These 241 h produced a dataset of 10,827 features, a rate of 44.9 features/person-hour. At that rate, the 1,300 h it took to deploy the ML approach taken by Can, Gerrits, and Kabadayi would yield about 58,400 records

claims.claim_text: A crowdsourcing approach like this is most suitable for datasets numbering perhaps 10,000–60,000 records
claims.verbatim_quote: To summarise in round numbers, a crowdsourcing approach like ours is most suitable for datasets numbering perhaps 10,000–60,000 records, assuming similar feature characteristics and data collection requirements

claims.claim_text: Below 10,000 records, approaches using desktop GIS should be considered
claims.verbatim_quote: Below 10,000 records, approaches using desktop GIS should be considered.

claims.claim_text: Above 60,000 records, ML approaches should be contemplated, but only if a project has access to the requisite expertise
claims.verbatim_quote: Above 60,000 records, ML approaches should be contemplated, but only if a project has access to the requisite expertise.

claims.claim_text: A combination of ML and crowdsourcing approaches might serve even large-scale projects
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, since training a model requires a manually produced dataset and a degree of manual error-checking, a combination of ML and crowdsourcing approaches might serve even large-scale projects.

claims.claim_text: A dataset big enough to justify ML will likely need a training dataset big enough to warrant crowdsourcing
claims.verbatim_quote: A dataset big enough to justify ML will likely need a training dataset big enough to warrant crowdsourcing, especially if the features or background are variable.

claims.claim_text: A typical project in history or archaeology may not be able to dedicate the personnel, infrastructure, or attention needed to incorporate ML successfully, but could deploy a collaborative geospatial system
claims.verbatim_quote: Today, a typical project in history or archaeology - often small, under-resourced, and pursuing several research activities - may not be able to dedicate the personnel, infrastructure, or attention needed to incorporate ML successfully, but could deploy a collaborative geospatial system for crowdsourcing map digitisation.

claims.claim_text: Deploying a crowdsourcing system requires a higher up-front investment in time and expertise than use of desktop GIS approaches, but it is feasible
claims.verbatim_quote: Deploying such a system requires a higher up-front investment in time and expertise than use of desktop GIS approaches, but it is feasible.

claims.claim_text: A project with a digital humanist or similar technologist with skills at the level of core Software Carpentry lessons can customise and operate a generalised platform such as FAIMS Mobile
claims.verbatim_quote: A project with a digital humanist or similar technologist with skills at the level of core Software Carpentry lessons (TheCarpentries, 2023) can customise and operate a generalised platform such as FAIMS Mobile to implement an effective crowdsourcing system.

claims.claim_text: Many customisable geospatial data collection systems attempt to make customisation as easy as possible
claims.verbatim_quote: Many of these systems attempt to make customisation as easy as possible, a goal at the heart of recent FAIMS redevelopment (ARDC, 2022)

claims.claim_text: In future the technical barriers to deploying such systems will likely decline
claims.verbatim_quote: in future the technical barriers to deploying such systems will likely decline

claims.claim_text: The deployment of the Map Digitisation FAIMS Mobile customisation facilitated the rapid digitisation (57 staff-hours; 184 volunteer-hours; 241 total) of 10,827 features found in Soviet topographic maps
claims.verbatim_quote: The deployment of the Map Digitisation FAIMS Mobile customisation facilitated the rapid digitisation (57 staff-hours; 184 volunteer-hours; 241 total) of 10,827 features found in Soviet topographic maps

claims.claim_text: All collected data was available daily for review, and a comprehensive, FAIR-compliant dataset was ready for analysis with less than 2 h of processing after collection
claims.verbatim_quote: All collected data was available daily for review, and a comprehensive, FAIR-compliant dataset was ready for analysis with less than 2 h of processing after collection.

claims.claim_text: Overall quality of the dataset was high, with some 2% of records having recoverable data omissions and an error rate under 6%
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall quality of this dataset was high. Some 2% of records had recoverable data omissions which were corrected during post-processing and subsequently minimised through the addition of validation. An accuracy check by staff covering 7% of digitised features indicated an error rate of under 6%

claims.claim_text: If staff time is the primary limiting resource, the approach becomes worthwhile for datasets no larger than about 4,500 features versus direct digitisation by expert staff
claims.verbatim_quote: If staff time is the primary limiting resource, our approach becomes worthwhile for datasets no larger than about 4,500 features versus direct digitisation of features by expert staff

claims.claim_text: The approach becomes worthwhile for datasets no larger than about 10,000 features versus volunteer digitisation using desktop GIS
claims.verbatim_quote: and no larger than about 10,000 features versus volunteer digitisation using desktop GIS

claims.claim_text: The approach remains the most efficient for datasets up to at least 60,000 features, above which automated approaches like ML should be considered
claims.verbatim_quote: It remains the most efficient approach for datasets up to at least 60,000 features, above which automated approaches like ML should be considered.

claims.claim_text: The approach is readily transferable to other mobile GIS systems and map corpora
claims.verbatim_quote: This approach is readily transferable to other mobile GIS systems and map corpora

claims.claim_text: More projects need to track and publish the expert and volunteer time required for digitisation, as well as digitisation speed, error rates, feature characteristics, and information complexity
claims.verbatim_quote: More projects - whether they use manual or automated approaches - need to track and publish the expert and volunteer time required for setup, training, support, and quality assurance related to map digitisation, as well as digitisation speed, error rates and types, the characteristics of the features being digitised, and the complexity of information extracted.
